awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The coordinated structural and physiological responses of trees to water stress: an organismal approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Drought is a global and increasingly frequent problem that threatens the vitality of forests and the many benefits they provide to society (including carbon sequestration, timber provisioning, and water cycle regulation). Whether trees thrive or falter during drought depends on how they respond to these stressful conditions. Despite many studies of leaf-level changes to photosynthesis and water use during drought, it is still unclear how trees make integrated and coordinated changes at the scale of the entire plant. For example, trees that change the angles of their leaves can reduce the radiation load at different levels of the canopy, reducing heat stress and water loss. This study investigates the coordinated adjustments of tree canopy structure and physiology under water stress using drought experiments in both growth chambers and in a forest that has a rainfall removal experiment. The investigators bring together traditional measurements of leaf and canopy gas exchange with novel remote sensing techniques that measure canopy structure and physiology. This project will provide interdisciplinary teaching, training, and learning experiences by collaborating with a non-profit organization (Math4Science) that promotes STEM, creating videos of 3D forests, mentoring undergraduate students, and exposing K-12 students from under-represented groups to STEM research.

The degree to which forests will continue to serve as carbon sinks and mitigate climate change hinges on whether trees can make physiological and structural adjustments to cope with changing environmental stressors. Most research to date on tree responses to drought has focused on how trees alter leaf-level physiology, phenology, and carbon mobilization and allocation. However, trees also make structural adjustments in response to drought (e.g., by changing leaf angles) to reduce radiation load and leaf temperature. The work extends current research on plant water use strategies, which is mostly focused on physiological responses at the leaf or ecosystem scales, to a new dimension - canopy structure (leaf angles). The investigators aim to answer the question "To what extent do trees respond to water stress through coordinated adjustments of canopy structure and leaf physiology, and by what mechanisms?" combining measurements of leaf and canopy gas exchange with novel remote sensing techniques that measure canopy structure and leaf physiology, including the Terrestrial Laser Scanning (TLS) and the Unmanned Autonomous Vehicle (UAV). By taking advantage of both classical and novel techniques, this project will provide new insights into the coordination of plant response to water stress over spatial (leaf to canopy) and temporal scales (short to long term). Including mechanical responses in physiological studies of drought at the scales of entire tree crowns will provide novel mechanistic insights into drought-science and will facilitate building comprehensive mechanistic approaches into ecosystem-scale models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PI Yang (University of Virginia), Co-Is Lerdau (University of Virginia), Novick (Indiana University), Phillips (Indiana University). Grant numbers: IOS-2005574, IOS-2006196.

The degree to which forests will continue to serve as carbon sinks and mitigate climate change

depends on whether trees can make physiological and structural adjustments to cope with changing environmental stressors. This project expands our mechanistic understanding of plant drought response by integrating leaf-level physiological changes with changes in canopy structure, particularly leaf angle changes. Leveraging leaf-level physiological measurements, terrestrial LiDAR, drone-based hyperspectral remote sensing, and field and growth-chamber drought experiments, our work demonstrates and quantifies plants’ physiological and structural responses to drought.

The development of an algorithm to estimate leaf angle from terrestrial laser scanning (TLS) data is crucial to the success of our project. We developed an open-source algorithm, TLSLeAF, to extract leaf angle data for hundreds of thousands of leaves in a forest using data collected by TLS. In addition, we developed a drone system that measures solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) and canopy hyperspectral reflectance of individual tree canopies. Leveraging these new techniques, we made novel measurements during our experiments to understand the physiological and structural responses of plants to drought and how those responses are integrated at the whole-plant level.

Our team has conducted both an indoor growth chamber experiment and two outdoor Throughfall Displacement Experiments (TDEs) to understand the mechanistic bases of physiological and structural responses of temperate forests to water stress. During the growth chamber experiment, we measured leaf gas exchange, fluorescence parameters, and leaf angle changes throughout the experiment. We used our TLSLeAF algorithm to quantify leaf angle variations of individual leaves (and the within-leaf variations in leaf surface angle). Our study reveals the mechanisms underlying SIF responses to drought, highlighting that both leaf physiological changes and structural changes result in changes in photosynthesis and SIF, allowing the use of SIF to track drought response at canopy, ecosystem landscape, and continental scales. We tested the canopy scale responses to drought and the use of SIF in our TDEs and were able to show that, with our mechanistic understanding of physiology and structure, we could use SIF to detect drought impacts at the canopy scale. SIF provides a clear signal of drought-induced reductions in carbon uptake.

To understand how leaf traits and canopy structure covary at the sub-continental scale, we sampled leaves of mature trees in Charlottesville, Virginia, and several major NEON sites. We measured leaf angles and key leaf traits of the Leaf Economics Spectrum (LES), including leaf mass per area (LMA) and nitrogen content (N%). These new activities provide a larger dataset than we had originally proposed, which allows us to examine the relationship between leaf angle and other leaf traits across a wide range of ecosystems and landscapes. We found that LMA is negatively correlated with leaf angle across the sites above, demonstrating the importance of incorporating canopy structural traits into the understanding of plant trait strategies.

Our team has trained three graduate students, four undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher. We have hosted high school students from public schools in central Virginia and New York City to demonstrate the use of new technology (e.g., drones) in ecology, and we have worked with an educational non-profit, Math4Science, as they develop science and math curricula.
